title: Digital Marketing Projects
text:
This section explores how demographic and behavioral insights from logistic regression modeling can inform United Airlines’ digital marketing strategy.
We focus on the following variables: - ✈️ Travel Purpose (Business vs. Leisure) - 🎫 Loyalty Status (Customer) - 👤 Age - 🚻 Gender




Insight: Business travelers are significantly more likely to report satisfaction than leisure travelers.
- Coefficient for Biztravel: +1.163, p < 0.001
- Interaction Customer * Biztravel: strong positive effect
Strategy: - 💼 Launch targeted digital campaigns like “Fly Smart. Work Smarter.”
- Highlight features that matter most to business travelers: WiFi, early boarding, legroom, and speed of check-in
Execution: - Segment ad groups by travel purpose using CRM data - Run LinkedIn Ads and Google PPC campaigns on business-related travel terms






Insight: While the individual coefficient for Customer (loyalty status) isn’t significant, the interaction with Biztravel is — loyalty combined with business travel boosts satisfaction.
Strategy: - 🎯 Promote loyalty tiers and benefits specifically to business flyers - 📧 Design emails and SMS campaigns with milestone tracking (“You’re 1 trip away from Gold status!”)
Execution: - Use past travel patterns to build lookalike audiences - Retarget frequent flyers with app-based upgrade promotions






Insight:
- Age has a negative main effect: older passengers are slightly less satisfied (Estimate = -0.014)
- However, this is moderated by service interactions (e.g., Age * Seat, Age * Delay, Age * WiFi)
Marginal Effect of Age:
- Average marginal effect = -0.00183, suggesting subtle but meaningful impact per year
Strategy: - 👵 For older segments: simplify online booking, enhance in-flight comfort - 🧑 For younger flyers: emphasize digital features, in-app boarding, fast check-in
Execution: - Age-customized landing pages and ads via programmatic targeting - Build personas based on combined age × travel purpose segments






Insight:
- Gender (Female = 1) shows a significant negative effect on satisfaction (Estimate = -0.529)
- But: interaction with Leg_room is positive, meaning improved legroom increases satisfaction among female travelers
Strategy: - 🪑 Promote spacious seating and comfort-focused features in female-centric channels - 💬 Consider running social campaigns focused on comfort, quiet zones, and premium seating
Execution: - Pinterest/Instagram creative targeting comfort features - Influencer campaigns showcasing “day-in-the-life” female business travel experiences


These strategies turn model-driven insights into highly actionable marketing approaches that respect demographic nuance while improving brand equity and passenger experience.

title: Customer Satisfaction Insights
text:
📂 Data and Source

Source: United Airlines 2015 Passenger Satisfaction Survey

Size: 120,000+ observations

Type: Structured survey data including:

Passenger demographics

Inflight service ratings

Operational delay information


Response Variable: Satisfaction (1 = Satisfied, 0 = Dissatisfied)

title: Customer Satisfaction Insights
text:
❗ Managerial Problem
United Airlines wants to improve passenger satisfaction in a competitive market.

What factors most strongly influence passenger satisfaction, and how can these insights inform operational and marketing strategies?

title: Customer Satisfaction Insights
text:

💼 Chief Marketing Officer (CMO)

✈️ Director of Customer Experience

🧠 Data Analytics & CRM Teams

title: Customer Satisfaction Insights
text:
❓ Research Questions

What inflight service factors significantly influence customer satisfaction?

How do operational issues like delays impact satisfaction?

How do customer demographics and travel purpose shape satisfaction levels?

What is the impact of seat comfort, legroom, and booking convenience?

title: Customer Satisfaction Insights
text:
📊 Analytics Objectives

Inflight Service Analysis: Measure effects of Wi-Fi, entertainment, food, etc.

Operational Factors: Evaluate delay impacts (departure, arrival)

Demographics & Purpose: Explore roles of age, gender, loyalty, and travel type

Comfort & Booking: Quantify influence of seating, legroom, and online tools

text:

Logistic Regression with interaction terms

Marginal Effects analysis

Classification Accuracy: 88.5% correctly predicted

Key Tools: R, Quarto, RevealJS

text:
📈 Key Findings

Business travelers significantly more likely to be satisfied

Loyalty boosts satisfaction when paired with business travel

Older age is negatively associated with satisfaction, mitigated by comfort features

Female passengers report slightly lower satisfaction but respond positively to legroom improvements

text:

🎯 Segmented Marketing: Targeted campaigns by age, gender, and travel type

🧾 Service Prioritization: Focus on Wi-Fi, seating comfort, and boarding ease

📈 Data-Driven Strategy: Use analytics to guide investment and policy

🔁 Customer Retention: Improve loyalty via high-satisfaction segments

title: Marketing Analytics
text:
This section presents the analytical work behind the project:
“What demographic factors and travel purpose predict customer satisfaction with United Airlines?”
We use logistic regression and marginal effects analysis to evaluate how factors such as travel purpose, loyalty status, age, and gender contribute to customer satisfaction.




Objective:
Examine how demographic characteristics and type of travel affect the likelihood of customer satisfaction.
Key Variables: - Biztravel (Business vs. Leisure) - Customer (Loyalty Status) - Age - Female (Gender)






Model: Logistic Regression
- Binary outcome: y = 1 if customer is satisfied, 0 otherwise
- Included interaction terms to account for combined effects (e.g., Age * Seat, Customer * Biztravel)
Diagnostics: - Pseudo R²: 0.566 — strong model fit
- % Correctly Predicted: 88.5% — high predictive accuracy
- Marginal Effect (Age): -0.00183 — older age slightly reduces satisfaction







Travel Purpose: Business travelers are significantly more likely to report satisfaction (Estimate = +1.163, p < 0.001)
Loyalty Status: Alone not significant, but the interaction with business travel is very strong (Estimate = +3.03)
Age: Negatively related to satisfaction but with nuanced interaction effects (e.g., service quality mitigates dissatisfaction)
Gender: Female travelers report lower satisfaction on average (Estimate = -0.528), but positively influenced by better legroom








Segmentation: Personalize marketing and operational improvements by age, gender, and travel purpose.
Targeted Service Improvements: Enhance seat comfort, WiFi, and in-flight services especially for demographics with lower satisfaction.
Model-Driven Campaigns: Use regression findings to inform digital marketing (see Digital Marketing Projects)



The analytics not only identify key predictors of satisfaction but also serve as a foundation for performance-based marketing strategies and service design.
